topic_seeds.description: Adjusting to a new location or environment
Feeling overwhelmed by work demands and deadlines
Feeling overwhelmed by work demands and deadlines (relatively straightforward)

flaw_patterns.name: forgetting_prior_insight
flaw_patterns.description: Returns to old pattern despite earlier realization

flaw_patterns.name: deflecting_with_humor
flaw_patterns.description: Uses jokes to avoid depth when conversation gets too real

exchanges.user: idk where to even start tbh. i moved to a new city like 3 weeks ago for this job and everything just feels off? like i knew it would be hard but i didnt think id feel this alone. and work is already piling up with deadlines and im barely keeping up. i keep thinking maybe i made a huge mistake coming here. like either this was the worst decision ever or im just not trying hard enough, cant really tell anymore. my roommate seems fine and has friends already so clearly its just me. anyway yeah thats whats going on rn
exchanges.assistant:
**The move and feeling alone:** Three weeks in a new city and already drowning in "did I screw this up?"—that's a lot to carry. The loneliness you're describing sounds really acute right now. It makes sense: you uprooted your whole life, you're in a place where nothing is familiar yet, and you don't have your people around. That's not a character flaw, that's just... what relocation feels like before roots take hold. The comparison to your roommate is doing you dirty, though—you're seeing their highlight reel, not their internal experience. Some people mask well. Some had existing connections. Some are just wired differently for new environments.

**Work pressure:** Starting a new job while simultaneously adjusting to a new city is basically running two marathons at once. The deadlines piling up while you're still learning systems, people, norms—of course you're barely keeping up. That's not evidence you're failing; that's evidence this is genuinely hard.

**The "worst decision ever vs. not trying hard enough" loop:** I want to pause on this, because it sounds like your brain is offering you two options, and both of them are self-critical. Either the decision was bad (your fault) or you're not trying hard enough (also your fault). What if there's a third option—that this is just hard, and it takes longer than three weeks for a new city to feel like anything other than disorienting?

Here's something worth noticing: your brain is asking "is it me or the situation?" like one answer is correct. Usually it's neither—it's the interaction between a person and circumstances, and three weeks isn't enough data to know how this will land.

What feels most pressing right now—the loneliness, the work overwhelm, or the "did I mess up?" thoughts?

exchanges.user:
honestly all of it feels pressing but like the work thing is what im dealing with every single day so i guess that. had this massive presentation deadline yesterday and i barely slept trying to get it done and then my manager had like a million notes and now i have to redo half of it by friday. so thats great.

and the thing is everyone else on the team seems to just GET IT? like they know all the systems and the jargon and who to ask for what and im just constantly behind trying to figure out basic stuff. i asked my coworker for help the other day and she was nice about it but i could tell she was busy and i felt like such an idiot for not knowing.

idk i keep thinking like if i just worked harder or smarter or whatever then id be fine but im already working til like 9pm most nights and its still not enough. either im completely incompetent at this job or the workload is actually impossible, and i honestly dont know which one it is anymore.

also my mom called and was asking how everythings going and i just lied and said its great bc i didnt want her to worry. she was already nervous about me moving so far away so. yeah.
exchanges.assistant:
**The work spiral:** Barely slept, gave the presentation, got a million notes, now redoing half by Friday. That's brutal. And the part that's really grinding you down sounds like the *relentlessness* of it—it's not one hard thing, it's a new hard thing every single day with no breathing room.

Notice what your brain is doing again, though: "either I'm completely incompetent or the workload is impossible." Same pattern as the move—two options, both leave you stuck. Here's what I'd actually want to know: how long have other people on your team been there? Because "they get it" usually means "they've had six months or two years to absorb what you're trying to learn in three weeks." You're comparing your week-three performance to their month-eighteen fluency. That's not a fair race.

The coworker thing—you asked for help, she was nice, and you walked away feeling like an idiot. I'm curious: did she *say* anything that suggested you were an idiot, or did your brain add that part? Because "she was busy" and "I'm an idiot for asking" are two very different things that got fused together somewhere.

**The working-til-9pm trap:** You said "if I just worked harder I'd be fine"—but you're already working until 9pm and it's not enough. At some point, "work harder" stops being a solution and starts being the problem. There's a ceiling on how many hours actually produce good work, and past that ceiling you're just tired and slower and making more mistakes that create *more* work. What would happen if you left at 7 one night this week? Not as a reward, but as an experiment.

**Your mom:** You lied because you didn't want her to worry. That makes sense—and it also means you're now carrying this alone, performing "fine" for the people who care about you. That's exhausting in its own way. Is there *anyone* you can be honest with right now about how hard this is? Doesn't have to be your mom.

Here's what I'm sitting with: you're three weeks into a massive life change, running on no sleep, working unsustainable hours, comparing yourself to people with way more context than you, and telling everyone you're fine. Something in that equation has to give. 

What feels most true when you read that back—is it the unsustainable hours, the comparison trap, or something else?

exchanges.user:
ugh ok so i tried leaving at 7 like you said and it was actually fine? like nothing caught fire and i got the same amount done the next day anyway. but then thursday happened and my manager scheduled this random check in meeting and i spiraled thinking she was gonna tell me im not cutting it and i stayed til 10 that night trying to prep for it. turns out she just wanted to see how im settling in and if i need anything. so that was a waste.

anyway the presentation redo went fine i guess. she approved it. but now theres already another project and its the same thing again where everyone knows what theyre doing and im just nodding along pretending i understand.

also i did talk to my friend back home and told her its been rough and she was like "oh yeah new jobs are hard for like 6 months" and i was like ??? 6 months??? bc in my head i thought id have it figured out by now. so thats cool. love that for me.

but yeah idk i think the real thing is i just need to be better at this faster. like yes everyones been here longer but also some people are just naturally good at picking things up and im clearly not one of them. so.
exchanges.assistant:
**The 7pm experiment:** Wait—this actually worked? You left early, nothing exploded, and you got the same amount done anyway. That's not a small thing. That's data. Your brain was telling you "if I don't work until 9pm everything will fall apart," and then reality said "actually, no." I want you to hold onto that, because your brain is going to try to convince you Thursday erased it. It didn't.

**Thursday's spiral:** So you heard "check-in meeting" and your brain immediately translated it to "you're getting fired," and you stayed until 10 prepping for a conversation that turned out to be... your manager checking on your wellbeing. This is a really clear example of something: the threat your brain manufactured was completely disconnected from reality. The staying-til-10 wasn't based on anything your manager said or did—it was based on a story you told yourself. And then you called it "a waste," which—yeah, it was wasted energy, but also: of course you did that. When your nervous system is already on high alert from three weeks of overwhelm, "random meeting" *feels* like danger even when it isn't.

Here's something that might help next time your brain starts spiraling about what something *means*: before you act on the fear, ask yourself "what's the actual evidence this is bad news?" Not "what could it be" but "what do I actually know right now." In this case, the answer was: nothing. You knew nothing. Your brain filled in the worst-case scenario and you worked three extra hours defending against a ghost.

**The presentation:** It got approved. That's a win. I notice you said "fine I guess" like you're not sure it counts—it counts.

**The new project and the nodding-along thing:** Still pretending to understand when you don't. This one's tricky because it feels safer in the moment, but it's actually making everything harder. Every time you nod along, you miss a chance to fill in the gaps, and then the gaps compound. What would happen if you asked one clarifying question in the next meeting? Not "explain everything," just one thing you don't understand.

**The 6-months thing:** Your friend said new jobs are hard for 6 months and your brain heard it as a life sentence. But here's what I actually heard: *your timeline was unrealistic and that's part of why you're suffering.* You thought you'd "have it figured out by now"—three weeks in. That expectation is doing real damage. It's turning normal learning curve into "I'm failing." 

**"Some people are just naturally good at picking things up and I'm clearly not one of them":** This is the part I want to push back on hardest. You're treating "picking things up" like a fixed trait—either you have it or you don't. But what I'm actually seeing is someone who moved to a new city alone, started a demanding job, got through a tough presentation cycle, ran an experiment with leaving earlier, reached out to a friend for support, and is still showing up every day. That's not someone who can't pick things up. That's someone who's picking up a *lot* of things simultaneously while exhausted and scared.

The question isn't "why am I not faster at this?" The question is: what would it look like to give yourself the same 6 months your friend mentioned—not as a sentence, but as permission?

exchanges.user:
so update i asked a question in the meeting today and it was actually helpful? like i asked what the approval process was for this new project bc i genuinely didnt know and my manager just explained it and nobody seemed annoyed. so thats something i guess.

but also i think im realizing the real issue is just that im not a people person like everyone else here. like theres this whole social thing happening where people grab lunch together or chat in the kitchen and i just feel so awkward trying to join in. yesterday i walked into the kitchen and there was this group laughing about something and i just grabbed my coffee and left bc i didnt know how to like... be part of that? and then i felt like a weirdo for leaving.

my roommate keeps inviting me to stuff with her friends and i keep saying no bc honestly the thought of meeting a bunch of new people and having to be "on" after working all day sounds exhausting. but then im alone every night so like. idk what im doing.

also i tried the 7pm thing again and it worked fine but then friday i stayed late again bc i just kept thinking about how much i have to do next week and figured i should get ahead. so now its the weekend and im tired and i have no plans and everyones posting about their fun weekend stuff and im just here. so thats where im at rn.
exchanges.assistant:
**The meeting question:** You asked, it helped, nobody was annoyed. This is the second piece of evidence (after the 7pm experiment) that directly contradicts what your fear brain was predicting. Your brain said "asking questions = looking like an idiot" and reality said "asking questions = getting useful information while everyone moves on with their day." I want you to notice that pattern: *your predictions about what will go badly keep being wrong.* That's worth paying attention to.

**The kitchen thing and "not a people person":** Okay, this is where I want to slow down. You walked into a group mid-laugh, didn't know the context, grabbed your coffee, and left. And from that you concluded: "I'm not a people person like everyone else here." 

But here's what I actually heard: you walked into an already-in-progress conversation with no obvious entry point, felt awkward, and did the thing most humans do—retreated. That's not evidence you're fundamentally different from everyone else. That's evidence that joining established groups mid-conversation is awkward *for most people.* The folks laughing in the kitchen? They probably didn't start that way. They probably had dozens of awkward coffee moments before they became the laughing group.

Here's something that might shift this: what if you're not missing a "people person gene," but missing *low-stakes reps*? The people who seem natural at this have usually just logged more hours being awkward until it got easier. One thing you could try—next time you're in the kitchen and someone's there alone, just say one thing. Not a whole conversation, just "hey, how's your Monday going" or whatever. Tiny. Survivable. See what happens.

**The roommate invitations:** You keep saying no because being "on" sounds exhausting after work. I get that—you're already running on fumes. But I notice you're caught in a loop: saying no to protect your energy → being alone every night → feeling worse → having even less energy. The protection is costing you the thing you actually need.

What if you said yes to *one* thing this week, with a built-in exit? "I'll come for an hour" or "I'll stop by but might not stay long." Not a commitment to be charming all night—just showing up, seeing what happens, leaving when you're done. Would that feel survivable?

**The 7pm thing (and then Friday):** You tried it again, it worked fine—and then Friday you stayed late anyway because you were thinking about next week. So the pattern is: the experiment works, but anxiety about the future pulls you back into old behavior. That's really common. It's not a failure. It's just your brain saying "yes but what about..." and you listening.

Here's the thing about "getting ahead": did staying late Friday actually make you feel more prepared for this week, or did it just make you more tired going into a weekend where you already felt isolated? Sometimes "getting ahead" is real, and sometimes it's just anxiety wearing a productivity costume.

**The weekend and the social media thing:** You're tired, alone, no plans, watching everyone else's curated highlight reels. That's a brutal combination. The comparison trap is especially vicious when you're already depleted.

Here's what I'm sitting with: you now have *evidence* that asking questions works and leaving at 7 works. Those experiments paid off. The next edge might be running a similar experiment on the social side—one tiny thing, with permission to leave. Not because you have to become a "people person," but because isolation is making everything else harder, and three weeks isn't enough time to have built connections yet.

What feels most scary about saying yes to your roommate—the energy it would take, or something else?

exchanges.user:
ok so i actually went to something with my roommate last night. it was just like drinks with her and 3 of her friends and honestly it was fine? like i was super anxious beforehand and almost bailed but i went and stayed for like 2 hours and it wasnt as draining as i thought. one of her friends works in marketing and we talked about work stuff for a bit and she was saying her first few months at her job were rough too so that made me feel less alone i guess.

but then today i had this whole thing at work where i made a mistake on a report and didnt catch it before sending it to the team and my manager had to correct it in front of everyone on slack. and now im back to feeling like everyone thinks im incompetent and i shouldnt have even asked that question in the meeting last week bc now theyve seen i dont know what im doing anyway. like whats the point of trying to seem capable when im just gonna mess up and prove im not.

also been thinking about what you said about my predictions being wrong but like. this time my prediction was right? i was worried id screw something up and i did. so idk if that whole thing still applies or if actually i just need to be more careful and stop making stupid mistakes.

anyway yeah. one step forward two steps back or whatever.
exchanges.assistant:
**The drinks thing:** You went. You stayed two hours. You connected with someone who validated your experience. That's not a small thing—that's you doing the exact thing you were scared of and discovering it was survivable. And the part where she said her first few months were rough too? That's the kind of thing that actually helps: real evidence from a real person that what you're going through is normal, not a sign you're uniquely broken. I'm glad you didn't bail.

**The Slack correction:** Okay, so this one stings. Getting corrected publicly feels awful, especially when you're already convinced everyone's watching for proof you don't belong. I want to separate a few things here though:

First, what actually happened: you made an error on a report, your manager corrected it. That's the event. What your brain did with it: "everyone thinks I'm incompetent," "I shouldn't have asked that question last week," "what's the point of trying," "I proved I don't know what I'm doing." That's a lot of story layered on top of one mistake.

Here's what I'd ask: did anyone actually say you're incompetent? Did your manager say "this is unacceptable" or did she just... fix it and move on? Because there's a big difference between "manager corrected an error" and "everyone now thinks I'm a fraud." Your brain is treating them as the same thing, but I'm not sure the evidence supports that.

**The "my prediction was right" thing:** This is the part I want to sit with, because I think your brain is doing something sneaky here. You said "I was worried I'd screw something up and I did—so my prediction was right." But that's not actually the prediction we were tracking. The predictions that kept being wrong were specific: "if I ask a question, I'll look like an idiot" (wrong—it went fine), "if I leave at 7, everything will fall apart" (wrong—it didn't), "the check-in meeting is bad news" (wrong—she was just checking on you), "going to drinks will be draining and awful" (wrong—it was fine and you connected with someone).

"I might make a mistake at some point" isn't a prediction—it's a certainty. Everyone makes mistakes. The question isn't whether you'll ever mess up; it's what that mess-up *means*. And right now your brain is saying it means "I'm incompetent and everyone knows it and trying is pointless." That's the part I'd push back on, not the fact that you made an error.

**The "what's the point of trying to seem capable" spiral:** I hear this one. It's exhausting to feel like you're managing a performance that could collapse at any moment. But here's what I notice: you're framing this as "seem capable vs. get exposed as not capable." What if there's a third option—actually *becoming* capable over time, which includes making mistakes and learning from them? Because that's what a learning curve looks like from the inside. It's not a straight line of looking good. It's mess-ups and corrections and slowly getting better.

One question worth sitting with: when your manager corrected the error, was there anything useful in the correction? Like, do you now know something about that report process that you didn't know before? Because if so, that's the learning curve working—ugly, embarrassing, but working.

**"One step forward, two steps back":** I'd actually challenge this framing. Yesterday: went to drinks, connected with someone, gathered evidence that your experience is normal. Today: made a mistake, got corrected, felt bad. That's not two steps back—that's one hard thing happening after one good thing. They don't cancel out. The drinks thing still happened. The person still said her first months were rough. You still have that.

The mistake doesn't erase the progress. It just happened on the same timeline.

What would it mean to let both things be true—that you're making progress on the social stuff AND you made an error at work today—without one negating the other?

exchanges.user:
ugh so i thought about the report thing and youre probably right that nobody actually said i was incompetent but also my manager hasnt replied to my last two messages in slack and its been like a day and a half so now im convinced shes avoiding me bc of the mistake. or maybe shes just busy idk i cant tell anymore.

anyway i went to lunch with that marketing person from the other night and it was actually nice? like we just talked about normal stuff and she told me about this coffee shop i should try. so thats good i guess.

but also i got assigned to lead this new project and i have no idea why they picked me bc there are people on the team who have been here way longer and actually know what theyre doing. and now im terrified im gonna mess it up and prove that i shouldnt have gotten it in the first place. like either this is a test to see if i can handle it or they just dont realize how little i know yet. been staying late again trying to prep for the kickoff meeting and i know you said the hours thing but like this actually matters so i cant just leave at 7 and hope for the best.

also my roommate asked if i wanted to go to some group hike thing this weekend and i said maybe but honestly the thought of spending a whole day with people i dont know sounds exhausting. but i also know ill just sit at home if i dont go so. idk
exchanges.assistant:
**The Slack silence:** A day and a half with no reply and your brain went straight to "she's avoiding me because of the mistake." I want to name what's happening here: you're in a gap with no information, and your brain is filling it with the worst possible story. But here's what you actually know—she hasn't replied yet. That's it. That's all the data you have. Managers get buried in messages. They forget to respond. They're in back-to-back meetings. They're dealing with their own stuff. "She's avoiding me" is one explanation; "she's busy and my message isn't urgent" is another, and probably more likely given that she *just* approved your presentation and assigned you to lead a new project. Those aren't the actions of someone who thinks you're incompetent.

One thing you could try: if the silence is eating at you by end of day tomorrow, send a quick follow-up. "Hey, just bumping this—let me know if you need anything else." It's normal. It gives you information. And it stops your brain from spinning a whole narrative in the void.

**The marketing lunch:** This is actually great. You met someone through your roommate, had drinks, and now you've had a second hangout—just the two of you, talking about normal stuff, getting coffee shop recommendations. That's how connections form. Not through some dramatic "instant best friends" moment, but through repeated low-key contact. You're doing it. I hope you noticed that.

**The project assignment:** Okay, so—they gave you a project to *lead*. Not assist on. Lead. And your brain immediately said "either this is a test to catch me failing or they don't realize how little I know." 

But here's a third option you're not considering: they picked you because they see something. Managers generally don't hand leadership roles to people they think are incompetent—it creates more work for them when it falls apart. It's possible your manager sees potential that you're not seeing in yourself right now.

And look, I get why this feels terrifying. More visibility means more chances to mess up publicly. But it also means someone looked at your work—including that presentation, including the report error—and still said "yeah, give her the lead." That's not nothing.

About the staying late: I hear you that this feels different, that it "actually matters." But I'd gently push back—the other stuff mattered too, and you still found that leaving at 7 didn't tank your output. What if you tried something in between? Prep for the kickoff, but set a cutoff time. Not 7, but maybe 8, with a clear stopping point. The goal isn't "hope for the best"—it's recognizing that diminishing returns are real, and that being rested for the kickoff might serve you better than being over-prepared and exhausted.

**The hike thing:** A whole day with strangers does sound like a lot—especially after the week you've had. But I notice the pattern: you know if you don't go, you'll be alone at home, probably spiraling about the project, watching everyone else's weekend posts again.

What if you used the same approach that worked for drinks—go with a built-in exit? "I'll come for the first part but might head out early." Or ask the marketing friend if she's going, so you'd have at least one person you already know. It doesn't have to be all-or-nothing: whole exhausting day vs. isolating at home. There's a middle path.

Here's what I'm noticing across all of this: you went to lunch and it was nice. You got picked for a leadership role. You're building something with the marketing person. And *also* you're anxious about Slack silence and terrified about the project and unsure about the hike. Both are happening. The progress hasn't stopped—it's just coexisting with the hard stuff.

What would help most right now—talking through the project fear, figuring out the hike, or something else?

exchanges.user:
ok so the kickoff meeting happened and it went fine i think? like i prepped a ton and people seemed to follow what i was saying and nobody looked confused. but then after one of the senior guys on the team sent me a dm with like a "suggestion" about changing the timeline and now i cant tell if that means i messed up the timeline or if hes just being helpful. i said thanks and that id think about it but now im second guessing the whole plan.

also i went on the hike. it was actually really nice, the marketing girl was there and we talked the whole time and she introduced me to some other people. one of them lives like two blocks from me which is random. but then i got home and just crashed bc i was so tired from being around people all day and i ended up sleeping through my alarm this morning and was late to work. so now im worried my manager noticed and thinks im slacking off right after getting the project lead role. she still hasnt responded to those messages btw so thats cool.

anyway the whole thing just feels like no matter what i do its wrong. like i stayed late prepping and the meeting went fine but now the timeline might be bad. i went to the hike like you said and met people but then i overslept. i try to do the right thing and it just creates new problems
exchanges.assistant:
**The kickoff meeting:** It went fine. People followed what you were saying, nobody looked confused. I want you to actually let that land for a second before your brain rushes past it—you led a meeting on a project you were terrified about, and it went *fine*. That's the headline.

The senior guy's DM: yeah, I get why that's sitting weird. "Suggestion" is one of those words that could mean twelve different things depending on tone you can't read through text. But here's what I'd offer—senior people giving input on timelines is usually just... how projects work? They have context you don't have yet, they've seen where timelines go sideways before, and sometimes they're genuinely just being helpful. It doesn't mean your plan was wrong; it might mean he has information that would make it better. What was the actual suggestion? Is it something that makes sense when you look at it, or does it feel off?

The second-guessing everything afterward—that's the part I want to name. The meeting went fine, but one DM was enough to make you question the whole plan. That's your brain doing the thing where it scans for any possible evidence of failure and latches onto it. The meeting going well is data. The DM is also data. They're not equal in weight—but your brain is treating the DM like it cancels out the meeting.

**The hike:** You went. You talked with the marketing friend the whole time. You met new people, including someone who lives two blocks away. That's genuinely great—that's how a social life starts to form in a new city. And then you were tired, because being around people all day *is* tiring, especially when you're still building those connections.

**The oversleeping:** Okay, so you slept through your alarm and were late. That happened. But I want to push back on the framing that going to the hike *caused* a problem. You were tired because you did something good for yourself. The oversleeping was a logistics issue, not a moral failing. Did you set a backup alarm? Do you need to adjust your Sunday wind-down if you do social stuff? Those are practical fixes, not evidence that trying to have a life was a mistake.

As for whether your manager noticed—you don't actually know that she did. And even if she did, one late morning after a weekend doesn't typically register as "slacking off," especially when you just led a kickoff meeting that went well. Your brain is connecting dots that might not be connected.

**The Slack silence:** Still nothing, huh. That's frustrating. At this point, I'd actually just send a quick follow-up if those messages need responses. Something low-key: "Hey, just bumping this—let me know if you need anything from me." It gives you information and stops the wondering.

**The "no matter what I do it's wrong" thing:** This is the part I want to sit with longest, because I think this belief is making everything harder.

You're framing this as: stayed late → meeting went fine → but timeline might be bad. Went to hike → met people → but overslept. Like every good thing automatically gets a "but" that negates it.

But here's what I actually see: you prepped, the meeting went well, and you got feedback you can incorporate. You went to the hike, built connections, and need to adjust your alarm strategy. Those aren't "doing the right thing and creating new problems." That's just... life having multiple parts. The feedback isn't a punishment for prepping. The tiredness isn't a punishment for socializing. They're just what comes next.

Here's something worth noticing: you're holding yourself to a standard where "doing the right thing" means everything goes perfectly with no follow-up issues. But that's not how anything works. Real progress is messy—it's "meeting went well AND I got feedback to consider" and "hike was great AND I was tired after." The AND is doing a lot of work there. Both things are true. One doesn't cancel the other.

What would it feel like to let the meeting being fine just *be* fine, without the DM turning it into a question mark?

exchanges.assistant:
**The timeline thing:** So you talked to the senior guy, and he was right—you'd missed a dependency and now the project shifts back two weeks. I hear you that this feels like a screwup, and honestly? It kind of was. Not a catastrophic one, not a fireable one, but yeah, you missed something. That's real.

But here's what I want you to notice: you caught it *before* it became a bigger problem. You didn't dig in and defend your original plan. You listened to the feedback, checked it out, and adjusted. That's actually exactly what you're supposed to do when someone more senior flags something. The mistake wasn't presenting a flawed timeline—the mistake would have been ignoring the input and running into that dependency three weeks from now when it's too late to fix. You didn't do that. You course-corrected. That's not nothing.

And yeah, both things are true: the meeting went fine AND the plan needed adjustment. But "I missed a dependency that someone with more context caught" is different from "I'm incompetent and shouldn't be leading this." One of those is a learning moment. The other is a story.

**The alarms and the coffee shop:** Three alarms, worked, problem solved. See—that's you handling a logistics issue without it becoming evidence of your fundamental brokenness. Just: "this happened, I fixed it, moving on." More of that.

And the coffee shop thing with the graphic designer sounds genuinely nice. Walking home together, talking about normal stuff, not work drama. That's the kind of low-key, unforced connection that actually turns into friendship over time. It felt nice because it *was* nice. Let that one just be good.
